name: Fraction, decimal and percentage equivalence - method selection 4

skills.name: Convert decimals greater than 1 to percentages
Write a fraction with a single digit denominator as a recurring decimal
Solve problems involving converting between fractions, decimals and percentages

explanations.A: Be careful. 1/3 is a recurring decimal but 0.3 is terminating (as it stops).
explanations.B: Not quite. 1/3 is a recurring decimal where as 33% which is 0.33 is a terminating decimal (as it stops).
explanations.C: Not quite. They cannot both be correct as 0.3 = 30% NOT 33%. Remember the fraction line means divide. Can you use this to find the decimal and percentage equivalents of 1/3 to see who is correct?
explanations.D: Both Tom and Katie have approximate answers: had they used the approximately equal symbol (a squiggly equals), their answers would have been acceptable. The fraction 1/3 produces a recurring decimal: 1/3 = 0.333333... = 33.333...% NOT 0.3 or 33%

explanations.A: 2/3 = 0.666666... or 0.6 recurring, which is more than 0.66. Therefore Jo is correct. Paul is incorrect as 2/3 = 0.666666 ... = 66.666... % NOT 66.6%
explanations.B: Not quite. 2/3 is a recurring decimal where as 66.6% which is 0.666 is a terminating decimal (as it stops).
explanations.C: Not quite. Remember the fraction line means divide. Can you use this to find the decimal and percentage equivalents of 2/3 to see who is correct?
explanations.D: Not quite, at least one of them is correct. Remember the fraction line means divide. Can you use this to find the decimal and percentage equivalents of 2/3 to see who is correct?

explanations.A: Not quite. Only one of the numbers is in its correct position. Converting them all into their decimal equivalents will help you to order them. Remember the line in the fraction means divide.
explanations.B: Not quite. Converting them all into their decimal equivalents will help you to order them. Remember the line in the fraction means divide.
explanations.C: Not quite. Only one of the numbers is in its correct position. Converting them all into their decimal equivalents will help you to order them. Remember the line in the fraction means divide.
explanations.D: Ascending order means starting with the smallest. 9/5 = 1.8 and 200% = 2. Therefore the correct order is 9/5, 1.8 and then 200%.

explanations.A: Not quite. Converting them all into their percentage equivalents will help you to order them. Remember percentage means out of 100.
explanations.B: Ascending order means starting with the smallest. Converting all values to percentages is a good place to start with this question: for 33/20, multiplying numerator and denominator by 5 gives 165/100 = 165%, and also 1.55 ✕ 100 = 155%. Now it becomes clear that 155% < 160% < 165%, meaning 1.55 < 160% < 33/20.
explanations.C: Not quite. Converting them all into their percentage equivalents will help you to order them. Remember percentage means out of 100.
explanations.D: Not quite. Converting them all into their percentage equivalents will help you to order them. Remember percentage means out of 100.

explanations.A: Be careful 1/5 does not equals 0.5. Use equivalent fractions, to give 1/5 a denominator of 10, to help you convert 1/5 to a decimal.
explanations.B: Be careful. 17% = 0.17 but we know our answer has to be bigger than 1.5. Remember to multiply by 100 to turn a decimal into a percentage.
explanations.C: Be careful 1/5 does not equals 0.05. Use equivalent fractions, to give 1/5 a denominator of 10, to help you convert 1/5 to a decimal.
explanations.D: ⅕ = 2/10 = 0.2, which means the calculation is 0.2 + 1.5 = 1.7. As all answers are given in percentage format, we need to convert 1.7 to a percentage. We do this by multiplying by 100. 1.7 x 100 = 170%

explanations.A: Not quite. Convert 1/4 to a decimal before adding it to 1.4. Use equivalent fractions, to give 1/4 a denominator of 100, to help you do this.
explanations.B: Not quite. 1/4 does not equals 0.4. Use equivalent fractions, to give 1/4 a denominator of 100, to help you convert 1/4 to a decimal.
explanations.C: Not quite. 1/4 is not the same as 0.25% Remember percentage means out of 100. Use equivalent fractions, to give 1/4 a denominator of 100, to help you convert 1/4 to a percentage.
explanations.D: 1/4 = 25/100 = 0.25. 0.25 + 1.4 = 1.65. As all answers are given in percentage format, we need to convert 1.65 to a percentage. We do this by multiplying by 100. 1.65 x 100 = 165%

explanations.A: Not quite. Region A only includes the numbers that are greater than 2/3 which are not smaller than 70%. Converting 2/3, using short division, and 70% into their decimal equivalents will help you see which region 0.6 should go in.
explanations.B: Not quite. Region B only includes numbers greater than 2/3 which are also smaller than 0.7. Converting 2/3, using short division, and 70% into their decimal equivalents will help you see which region 0.6 should go in.
explanations.C: Let’s convert all the values to decimals to make it easier to compare: ⅔ = 2 ÷ 3 =0.666... The other value of 70% = 70/100 = 70 ÷ 100 = 0.7. Given these values, we can decide that 0.6 belongs in region C because 0.6 is smaller than 0.7 but is not bigger than 0.666...
explanations.D: Not quite. Converting 2/3, using short division, and 70% into their decimal equivalents will help you see which region 0.6 should go in.

explanations.A: Let’s convert all the values to decimals to make it easier to compare: 75% = 75/100 = 75 ÷ 100 = 0.75 and ⅘ = 8/10 = 0.8. The value 0.806 belongs in region A, being bigger than 0.75 or 75% but larger than 4/5 or 0.8
explanations.B: Not quite. Region B only includes numbers bigger than 75% which are also smaller than 4/5. Converting 4/5, using equivalent fractions, and 75% into their decimal equivalents will help you see which region 0.806 should go in.
explanations.C: Not quite. Region C only includes numbers smaller than 4/5 which are not bigger than 75%. Converting 4/5, using equivalent fractions, and 75% into their decimal equivalents will help you see which region 0.806 should go in.
explanations.D: Not quite. Converting 4/5, using equivalent fractions, and 75% into their decimal equivalents will help you see which region 0.806 should go in.

explanations.A: Not quite. Region A includes all those number bigger than 0.15 which are not smaller than 1/4, therefore 0.3 could go here. Use equivalent fractions to turn 1/4 into a decimal then try to fill in each region with a suitable number. Which region can we not fill?
explanations.B: Not quite. Region B includes all those number bigger than 0.15 that are also smaller than 1/4, therefore 0.2 could go here. Use equivalent fractions to turn 1/4 into a decimal then try to fill in each region with a suitable number. Which region can we not fill?
explanations.C: Not quite. Region C includes all those number smaller than 1/4 that are not bigger than 0.15, therefore 0.1 could go here. Use equivalent fractions to turn 1/4 into a decimal then try to fill in each region with a suitable number. Which region can we not fill?
explanations.D: Let’s convert all the values to percentages to make it easier to decide: 0.15 = 0.15/1 = 15/100 = 15% and ¼ = 5/20 = 25/100 = 25%. There are many, many examples (an infinite number!) of percentages that are bigger than 15%, equally so for smaller than 25% and the intersection too (for example 20%). Therefore, the region that will never contain a value is region D.

explanations.A: Not quite. Region A includes all those numbers bigger than 0.25 which are not smaller than 1/5, therefore 0.3 could go here. Use equivalent fractions to turn 1/5 into a decimal then try to fill in each region with a suitable number. Which region can we not fill?
explanations.B: 1/5 = 2/10 = 0.2. Therefore, region B contains all the numbers that are bigger than 0.25 and smaller than 0.2. There is no such number, therefore region B is impossible to fill.
explanations.C: Not quite. Region C includes all those number smaller than 1/5 that are not bigger than 0.25, therefore 0.1 could go here. Use equivalent fractions to turn 1/5 into a decimal then try to fill in each region with a suitable number. Which region can we not fill?
explanations.D: Not quite. Region D includes all those numbers that are not bigger than 0.25 and that are not smaller than 1/5, therefore 0.21 could go here. Use equivalent fractions to turn 1/5 into a decimal then try to fill in each region with a suitable number. Which region can we not fill?
